explanations.summary: Muscle fiber recruitment: (1) Size principle - small motor neurons (Type I) recruited first, then larger (Type II); (2) Type I = slow, fatigue-resistant, used first; (3) Type II = fast, powerful, recruited for high force; (4) Most muscles have mixed fiber types.

whyCorrect.a: Size principle: Motor units are recruited from smallest (weakest, Type I) to largest (strongest, Type II). Small motor neurons have lower thresholds and are activated first.
whyCorrect.d: Most human skeletal muscles contain BOTH Type I (slow oxidative) and Type II (fast glycolytic) fibers in varying proportions depending on muscle function.

whyIncorrect.b: Type I fibers are for SUSTAINED activity and fatigue resistance, NOT peak force. Peak force requires Type II fast-twitch fibers.
whyIncorrect.c: During LOW intensity activity, Type I fibers are used FIRST (not Type II). Type II is recruited only for high-intensity/high-force activities.
